metadata.title: Introduction to TensorFlow for Data Science | by Rashi Desai | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Introduction to TensorFlow for Data Science
metadata.description: For a long time, I wanted to learn TensorFlow and I finally decided to start learning this month. I used TensorFlow when I was in the robotics team during my undergrad but that was superficial…

all_paragraphs: For a long time, I wanted to learn TensorFlow and I finally decided to start learning this month. I used TensorFlow when I was in the robotics team during my undergrad but that was superficial knowledge.

Google developed TensorFlow and it is one of the most popular and widely used libraries for developing and deploying Machine Learning and other algorithms that has a large number of mathematical operations to perform.

Google launched TensorFlow to introduce an ecosystem that provides a collection of workflows to develop and train models, for implementing Machine learning in almost all applications. Actually, we all use TensorFlow so often without realizing it’s use: Google Photos or Google voice, you are using TensorFlow models indirectly, they work on large clusters of Google hardware and are powerful in perceptual tasks.

TensorFlow has over 150K GitHub stars and about a whopping 83.2K GitHub forks. TensorFlow’s open-source repo on GitHub is a wonderful resource. This blog is a first-hand introduction to TensorFlow, how to use it, and why to use it?
With TensorFlow, move beyond off-the-shelf routines.
The core components of TensorFlow are tensors and computational graph that is across nodes through edges. So, let’s first understand what TensorFlow is made of:

Data for machine learning generally requires computation in some form and therefore, we often see data representation done numerically. To define a tensor: it is a container that can house data in N dimensions.

In a nutshell, tensors are mathematical objects used to describe physical properties like scalars and vectors. In fact, from what I learned, tensors are merely a generalization of scalars and vectors; a scalar is a zero-rank tensor, while a vector is a first-rank tensor. You can determine the rank of a tensor by the number of directions required to represent it. That also signified by the dimensionality of the array.
Now that we know what a tensor is, let’s understand the Flow part of TensorFlow:

A computational graph is an entity defined as a directed graph where each node corresponds to certain mathematical operations. Basically, computational graphs are a mean of expressing and evaluating some mathematical expression at each node.

Machine Learning is the call of hour and so, various companies from a wide range of industries need tools and resources to implement ML and solve their biggest problems. From healthcare to social networks and e-commerce, TensorFlow is used by everyone and for many things!

When I started learning more in-depth, the first thing I researched is the prevalence and usage of TensorFlow in the world, and the perfect webpage for case studies, use cases, and popularity is https://www.tensorflow.org/about/case-studies. Some of the use cases of TensorFlow from the webpage are below:
Airbnb: Categorizing Listing Photos at Airbnb
Lenovo: TensorFlow Optimizations for the Intel® Xeon® Scalable Processor
Coca-Cola: Machine Learning with TensorFlow enabled mobile Proof-of-Purchase at Coca-Cola
Lenovo: Lenovo Intelligent Computing Orchestration using TensorFlow to help accelerate the intelligent revolution
PayPal: Using TensorFlow to stay at cutting edge of Fraud Detection
GE: General Electric trained a neural network using TensorFlow to identify anatomy on MRI on brain
Twitter: Ranking Tweets on the home timeline with TensorFlowyou name a company and TensorFlow is being used in Machine Learning engineering.

As Machine Learning grows to strengthen its grasp on the industry and the rapidly expanding technological world around us, it is seeing the rise of TensorFlow, ML and Deep Learning frameworks exponentially.

TensorFlow eases out the PM cycle of data acquisition, model build and development, and predicting outcomes with fine-tuning future predications. Some of the beginner projects that can be done with TensorFlow are —

One of the very frequent projects I came across in the times of COVID-19 is the Smart Gateway Screening for masks — a model that detects from a stream of video input whether the screened person is wearing a mask [source]
Definitely worth a visit for more exciting projects here: https://experiments.withgoogle.com/collection/ai

That’s it from my end for this blog. Thank you for your time reading the TensorFlow intro! I hope you enjoyed the article. Do let me know if you already know TensorFlow or are learning and what projects are you looking forward to working on in your data journey?
Disclaimer: The content in this article is a personal view and does not represent a strict outlook.
